description:
Whenua Tapu Crematorium Open Day, Whenua Tapu Crematorium Open Day
Built in 1982, Whenua Tapu Crematorium is a beautiful facility that has served thousands of families.

Hear about the history of the chapel and what it’s like to operate a crematorium from the staff that operate it. You can also do a walk-through of the crematorium (optional).

Cremation is the common choice is NZ when it comes to death, with over 70% of Kiwis choosing it. Traditionally Māori and Pacifica families always chose burial, however there is a slow change happening in that space also. We are passionate about de mystifying what cremation is so families can feel informed about the choices they make.

Come along as we open Whenua Tapu Crematorium to the public and answer any questions you may have.


Cost: Free
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/whenua-tapu-crematorium-open-day/


Health & Safety:
Fire alarms on site, first aid kit on site. Staff will act as wardens in emergency.

Plenty of parking on site and toilets on site too.

description:
Wonderful Wahine: Women in the Cemetery, This tour features entertaining stories of women – settlers and Māori – who lived in Wellington and helped shape its history. They are wives, daughters, mothers, housewives and heroines: an artist, a nurse, a teacher and a song-writer, as well as boarding house operators, shopkeepers and a respected tribal leader who signed the Treaty of Waitangi.
Children 12 & under: free (no ticket required). Well-behaved dogs on leads welcome.

description:
Wrights Hill Fortress - Labour Day Open Day, In conjunction with the Wellington Heritage Festival the Fortress will be open for public inspection on Monday, Labour Day.

Bring the family and friends for a look at the World War two coastal battery history.

Self -guide yourselves through the tunnels with a free map and history pamphlet and see historic photos, weapons displays and try your hand at blank firing under strict supervision. Touring generally takes about one hour. Bring a torch for some fun.

Limited car parking at the top of Wrights Hill-please Park sensibly.

Moderate admission prices:

Family - $20

Adults - $10

Under 15 - $5

description:
Wrights Hill Fortress Open Day, Visit the World War Two Fortress in Karori and learn about New Zealand's war efforts in the 1940's. Photos, displays and DVD of a 9.2 inch gun firing.
Wrights Hill Fortress Open Day - Labour Day October 27th. Come and see WW2 history at the Karori Fortress. Self- guided tours take about one hour. Historic Photos, DVD of a huge 9.2 inch gun firing and other displays. Refreshments available. Entry cash only.
Entertainment for the whole family, and friends at the World War Two Fortress in Karori.
Spend one hour of more self-guiding yourselves through the 620 metres of underground tunnels.
Bring a torch for some fun and stout footwear please.
Families $20, Adults $10, Child $5. NO EFTPOS - CASH ONLY please.
Military living interest displays and historic photos.
Limited parking at the top of the hill. Please park sensibly.

Bookings not required.
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../wrights.../

description:
Climate Kōrero Pōneke - Storytellers Night # 3, Join us for Climate Kōrero #3!

After our first two sold-out events, we are thrilled to invite you to the third installment of Climate Kōrero - an evening dedicated to celebrating the inspiring mahi of individuals and organisations driving climate action in our communities.

We'll hear from four passionate speakers who will share their journeys, insights, and practical ways you can get involved. The event follows the Pecha Kucha format - each speaker presents 20 slides, with each slide shown for 20 seconds. This fast-paced visual format is a great way to share stories and keeps everyone on their toes! After each presentation, you’ll have the chance to kōrero directly with the speakers, so bring your questions and curiosity.

Why should you come along?
* Get inspired by changemakers in the climate action space
* Free kai to enjoy while you listen and connect
* Meet like-minded people and grow your climate action network
* Discover opportunities to get involved, including funding through the Climate and Sustainability Fund

Our speakers:
* Gareth Hughes – Wellbeing Economy Alliance
* Ellie Clayton – Kaicycle
* Emma Osborne & Gareth Jardine – EkeRua Rebicycle
* Orini Rokx-Taratu & Santino Morehu – Future Unity

Event details:
* 5:00–5:30pm – Arrive, grab some kai, and explore info on climate action in Pōneke
* 5:30pm – Welcome and first two speakers
* Intermission – More kai and kōrero
* Final two speakers – Then wrap-up and mingling

Whether you're new to climate action or already involved, this is a great chance to connect, learn, and be inspired.

Come and kōrero with us!

description:
E-Waste Drop off Day Johnsonville, Drop off your unwanted electronic products during this drive-thru event!
Held in the carpark of Onslow College: New Entrance - 155 Burma Rd, Johnsonville - Please check the posts in 'discussion' for more details.
Staff will unload everything for your convenience.
We are proud to accept donations for Variety – the Children’s Charity.
FREE OF CHARGE
Computers, Monitors, Tablets and Small Devices, Laptops, Routers and Modems, Mice, Servers, UPS, Cameras, Hifi Stereo Amps and Speakers, Mobile Phones, Car Batteries, Wiring & Cabling, Mainframe Circuit Boards, etc.
CHARGED ITEMS:
• $2 Fluorescent Tubes (Normal Light bulbs not accepted)
• $3 for Media and DVD player, Keyboards, Toner Cartridges, Desk phones
• $5 per kg - Mixed Batteries
• $5 for Heaters, Microwaves, Vacuum Cleaners, AV Equipment, Small Home Appliances
• $10 for Printers, Scanners, Fax Machines
• $20 Dishwashers, Washing Machines, Dryers, Flat screen TVs
• $40 Fridges, Heatpumps and Air Con units
• $60 Large Photocopiers
Please understand charges above are for sharing the recycling cost.
Eftpos and cash accepted on site.
What we don't accept:
- CDs & DVDs
- Floppy discs
- LED lightbulbs
- Household lightbulbs
- LPG gas bottle
- Medical devices
- Glass
Other hazardous waste (e.g.)
- Paint
- Garden waste
- General chemicals
- Furniture (e.g.)
- TV cabinets

Fundraiser - Seaweed and Ocean-inspired Art Sale at the South Coast Arts Trail, Fundraiser - Seaweed and Ocean-inspired Art Sale at the South Coast Arts Trail
Purchase ocean-inspired art and support marine conservation!
Seaweed and ocean-inspired artworks by Explore Your Coast Founder Nicole Miller will be on show at the 2025 South Coast Arts Trail in Island Bay, 13 & 14 September 2025 (10am to 4pm).

Nicole will be at the Presbyterian Church both days with the immersive 360° video tours of Wellington's Blue Belt and Taputeranga Marine Reserve. Come along, experience Wellington's underwater world, and be inspired to dive into our local marine reserve!

All profits from artworks sold support the marine conservation and outreach initiatives of Explore Your Coast.

description:
GDNZ 2025 Shelly Bay Cleanup, *POSTPONED TO 18TH OF OCTOBER*
Join Ghost Diving New Zealand for a community cleanup!

This will be an ocean and shore based clean up targeting rubbish in and around the Wellington foreshore.

Scuba divers, free divers and shore crew all needed! Be prepared to get wet and dirty!

DATE: Saturday October 18th 2025

TIMES:
9.00am - Registrations open
9:45am - Briefing
10.00am - Divers in the water
2.00pm Clean-up and pack down

LOCATION: Shelly Bay - look for the GDNZ signs.

Scuba Divers who wish to participate must have a minimum of 30 logged dives and be comfortable working in low / zero visibility.
Scuba and Free Divers must provide their own gear and tanks. If you also have your own catch bag(s) or float boat for collecting rubbish, please bring this along and ensure they are named.
If you would like to join in the fun and participate as part of the shore crew, you will need to make sure you are wearing fully covered shoes and bring a pair of gardening gloves... also be prepared to get dirty!

ALL PARTICIPANTS, SHORE CREW AND DIVERS MUST REGISTER ON ARRIVAL.

PLEASE NOTE:
• This is a free, family friendly event, but children must be supervised at all times by an adult.
• Closed toe footwear must be worn for safety.
• Please bring your own hand protection (gardening gloves or similar).
• Don’t forget your own water bottle and bring sunscreen if it’s a warm day.
• Dress for the weather (warm clothes and jackets)
• There will also be plenty of work for non-divers to get involved.
Should the event be cancelled due to circumstances out of our control, notification will be given on the Facebook page the night before. Please remember to check prior to the event.
We look forward to seeing you there!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!
Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life and learn new skills along the way.
Book below and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.
Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.
These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.
Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.
This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Paritua, The Botanist & Sea Shepherd!, Paritua, The Botanist & Sea Shepherd!
We've teamed up with Paritua Vineyard and Sea Shepherd NZ to bring you a fantastic evening of dining and drinking excellent wine! We'll be serving a four course plant based dinner, matched with Paritua wines, in support of Sea Shepherd New Zealand.
⁠
Each dish draws its inspiration from the sea with a kiwi twist, designed by our head chef Stephanie Hinton. Stephanie has recently moved back to New Zealand after 16 years cheffing in London, and running acclaimed vegan businesses there. Each course is paired with organic and vegan wines presented by Ollie Kettle and Josh Pointon of Paritua Wines. Proceeds from tickets sold will be donated directly to Sea Shepherd to help protect our oceans.

Numbers are limited, so gather your friends and book early for an unforgettable night of food, wine and ocean conservation.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we are delighted and look forward to a day of planting, learning, connecting and creating at the Ruamahanga farm.
Three kilometers west of Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are restoring an oxbow wetland and the riperian edge of the Ruamanhanga river.
Our hosts: Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will be demontrating to us how this restoration work provides a platform for Te Reo o te Wai, and how the arts and conservation programme for local primary children is filling a need for experiential learning.
Children and young people learn about ecology, practice hands-on conservation and find their own ways to ceatively expressing what it means for them to connect to special places withing the Wairarapa Moana.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10:30 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10:30 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses. Free registration opens soon

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (weed-busting fun)
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.
Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Spring Flora - Guided Walk, During one this one-hour spring walk, which will be in the lower Main Garden, we will enjoy the Garden’s re-emergence from winter, marked by the burst of leaf and flower buds and possibly fully opened spring flowers. We will evoke the spirit of Flora, the Roman Goddess symbolising fertility and blossoming.

Meet at the Founders’ Entrance, Glenmore Street.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion
Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

In the Discovery Garden:
Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear

Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray

Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators

Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

In the Treehouse:
🍯 Pollination tastings – Sample honey, olive oil, and chocolate. Delicious local products made possible by pollinators.

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

About this Event

Fairy Potion Garden: An Enchanted Workshop (1.5 hours)
Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨
This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.
Includes:
🌸 Potion making with a fairy host
🌼 Take-home fairy potion bottle
🧚‍♀️ Enchanting stories and magical games ✨ Perfect for kids aged 5 and up
A fluttery, fun-filled time for every little fairy and forest friend! 🌿💫

Please note that we are not registered childcare providers, which means an adult responsible for each child must remain on the premises. The venue is also a café restaurant with other areas where parents can chill while the workshop is running.

description:
North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Sunday, 21 December 2025, North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Sunday, 21 December 2025
Be whisked away on the North Pole Express to meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.

About this Event


Public sales commence 1 September 2025.
Nice List presale: 12pm, 25 June 2025 - 5pm, 1 July 2025. Password required.
No tickets will be held during presale, any remaining tickets will be offered to the public from 12pm on 1 September 2025. To join the 'Nice List' visit the .
If you would like to purchase a private carriage for your group on this service, please email prior to 15 June 2025.



Join The Magical Journey to meet Santa!
Your tickets include:
Entertainers
Carolling
Iced cocoa
Cookies
Souvenir Mug
A special souvenir from Santa
Santa
Extra surprises along the way
Our Candy Class and Claus Class Guests travel in comfort and receive extra treats along the way.


Prepare to be surrounded by the magic and wonder of the Christmas season!
Families will love the magical train ride in one of our specially decorated carriages. You’ll meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.
Set to the sounds of carols passengers are invited to join us to be whisked away on the North Pole Express. Delight in the magic of Christmas as the train departs for a journey to collect Santa who has been magically transported to an undisclosed location along the tracks.
From the distance the North Pole Express arrives then the train Conductors invite you and the other passengers to climb aboard shouting “All aboard!”.


All Aboard
During the first leg of the journey wide-eyed children of all ages are invited to engage with characters who are eager to hear what makes the Christmas season special to them.
You’ll meet the conductor, and join in the fun singing and dancing with your hosts and a few other characters who will appear in your carriage on the journey.
At the 'North Pole' Cocoa Class passengers enjoy their iced chocolate from their souvenir mug, and a delicious cookie served by our North Pole Express hosts. Candy and Claus Class passengers will be served aboard the train on the way to the North Pole.
Along the journey Santa appears in your carriage to present each passenger with their very own Christmas ornament. During the trip, characters in each carriage lead passengers in carolling and entertainment as the train makes its way back home.
Children UNDER 2 years (0-23 months) and travelling on the lap of an Adult are FREE. All Passengers 2 years old and over must hold a purchased ticket.

Please note: Seating in our Candy and Claus Classes is strictly limited. Candy and Claus Class Guests receive some extra surprises and treats along the way.
Seating in all carriages is arranged in a configuration of 4 seats as per normal train travel. NPE always endeavour to ensure those who book more than 4 seats are seated in close proximity to each other to ensure they can enjoy the experience together. Children under the age of 2 and travelling on the lap of an adult travel for free.
Wheelchair access: Due to the age and design of the carriages it is not possible to board whist seated in a wheelchair as the entrance is stairs and the doorways are very narrow. However we will be pleased to convey passengers of limited mobility whenever possible provided they can step onto the train from the platform, climbing a step and move to their reserved seats with the help of an able bodied carer. Our crew would assist guiding the passenger up the step onto the train and arrange for the storage of the wheelchair in the guards van. The wheelchair must be able to be folded up and cannot be used on the train. Please let us know when booking if you need wheelchair assistance.

Photo credit: John Bovis
label: Family Friendly

description:
North Pole Express Kapiti: 5pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025, North Pole Express Kapiti: 5pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025
Be whisked away on the North Pole Express to meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.

About this Event


Public sales commence 1 September 2025.
Nice List presale: 12pm, 25 June 2025 - 5pm, 1 July 2025. Password required.
No tickets will be held during presale, any remaining tickets will be offered to the public from 12pm on 1 September 2025. To join the 'Nice List' visit the .
If you would like to purchase a private carriage for your group on this service, please email prior to 15 June 2025.



Join The Magical Journey to meet Santa!
Your tickets include:
Entertainers
Carolling
Iced cocoa
Cookies
Souvenir Mug
A special souvenir from Santa
Santa
Extra surprises along the way
Our Candy Class and Claus Class Guests travel in comfort and receive extra treats along the way.


Prepare to be surrounded by the magic and wonder of the Christmas season!
Families will love the magical train ride in one of our specially decorated carriages. You’ll meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.
Set to the sounds of carols passengers are invited to join us to be whisked away on the North Pole Express. Delight in the magic of Christmas as the train departs for a journey to collect Santa who has been magically transported to an undisclosed location along the tracks.
From the distance the North Pole Express arrives then the train Conductors invite you and the other passengers to climb aboard shouting “All aboard!”.


All Aboard
During the first leg of the journey wide-eyed children of all ages are invited to engage with characters who are eager to hear what makes the Christmas season special to them.
You’ll meet the conductor, and join in the fun singing and dancing with your hosts and a few other characters who will appear in your carriage on the journey.
At the 'North Pole' Cocoa Class passengers enjoy their iced chocolate from their souvenir mug, and a delicious cookie served by our North Pole Express hosts. Candy and Claus Class passengers will be served aboard the train on the way to the North Pole.
Along the journey Santa appears in your carriage to present each passenger with their very own Christmas ornament. During the trip, characters in each carriage lead passengers in carolling and entertainment as the train makes its way back home.
Children UNDER 2 years (0-23 months) and travelling on the lap of an Adult are FREE. All Passengers 2 years old and over must hold a purchased ticket.

Please note: Seating in our Candy and Claus Classes is strictly limited. Candy and Claus Class Guests receive some extra surprises and treats along the way.
Seating in all carriages is arranged in a configuration of 4 seats as per normal train travel. NPE always endeavour to ensure those who book more than 4 seats are seated in close proximity to each other to ensure they can enjoy the experience together. Children under the age of 2 and travelling on the lap of an adult travel for free.
Wheelchair access: Due to the age and design of the carriages it is not possible to board whist seated in a wheelchair as the entrance is stairs and the doorways are very narrow. However we will be pleased to convey passengers of limited mobility whenever possible provided they can step onto the train from the platform, climbing a step and move to their reserved seats with the help of an able bodied carer. Our crew would assist guiding the passenger up the step onto the train and arrange for the storage of the wheelchair in the guards van. The wheelchair must be able to be folded up and cannot be used on the train. Please let us know when booking if you need wheelchair assistance.

Photo credit: John Bovis

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free

These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.

Activities include:
- Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
- Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
- Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
- Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.

Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!

We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!

You will have the option of creating your orb into a hanging planter or a unique decoration for your room or garden. Teens will learn basic hand-building techniques to create with clay.

The pieces will be decorated with underglaze and fired. All art will be ready for pickup approximately 3 weeks later depending on drying times.

Recommended age for this workshop is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

- learn how to glaze your creations
- learn techniques to create art that will withstand the firing process.

Creations will be fired at the end of each term and ready to collect at the beginning of next.

description:

Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.
Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.
Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!
Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.

Best suited to ages 8-12 $65 per tamariki.

And don’t miss the FREE face painting (10am-12pm) – what or who could you become!?
Free, drop-in. Limited capacity, first come first served!
Access information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku (toilet) at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. You can find more accessibility information here. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

with support from Shepherds Reign - completing this un-holy trinity with their commanding, tribal-infused metal.

Three bands. One stage. No second chances.

As always, Brewtown will be serving up heaps of unbeatable beverage options from our festival bars ft. craft beer, bourbon, wine, non-alcs and more.
And we’ve got a line-up of serious feeds from some of the regions top foodies.

Score your ticket. Feel the volume. Get AMPED UP!

Fiesta Chilena is a vibrant celebration of Chilean culture and independence. This family-friendly event will showcase Chilean traditions, music, dance, food, and arts. Attendees will experience the rich heritage of Chile while enjoying a fun and festive atmosphere.

description:
Christmas on the Coast, Christmas on the Coast
Get ready to sparkle, Christmas on the Coast is back! Register now to be a float or stall for the 2025 Christmas Parade - www.kapiticoast.govt.nz/do-it-online/forms/register-your-float-or-stall-for-the-2025-christmas-parade/

Join us on Saturday 13 December, from 11am–3pm at Mazengarb Reserve for a festive family day filled with cheer.

At 11 am, catch the colourful Christmas float parade as it travels from Paraparaumu College along Mazengarb Road to the reserve, then stay on for an afternoon of festival fun.

Enjoy free activities like games, face-painting, live entertainment, a bounce zone, and visits to Santa’s grotto. Bring a picnic or grab a bite from one of our food trucks, and don’t forget to bring a can for the Kāpiti Foodbank collection.

For more info, visit www.kapiticoast.govt.nz/Christmas
________________________
There’s no rain date for this event.

description:
Crash Bandihoot & DJ Danger, Yes!!

Welly party favourites Crash Bandihoot return to Petone for another epic Jazz Festival party! Last year tickets sold out and the vibe was awesome!

Crash Bandihoot are a colourful raucous New Orleans street style party brass band known for bringing the weekend carnival vibes. Expect soaring horns and driving grooves and rhythms from the group representing Aotearoa NZ in both Australia and Brazil.

Plus support from the amazing DJ Danger spinning an all vinyl set!

Reviews of Crash Bandihoot -

Terrifying - Under The Radar
A plague - Destiny Church
Blew the roof off! - Wunderbar Lyttleton
Big. Bad. Brass. - Performance Arcade
You guys are NUTS. BEST GIG. EVER!! - 5Tapped

See you there!

DJ Danger - 7pm
Crash Bandihoot - 8pm

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/
label: Festivals

description:
Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia, Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia
Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

About the Day of the Dead
The Day of the Dead tradition dates back to pre-Hispanic times, when a tribute was paid to death; the tribute took place from the last week of October to the first days of November.

Prehispanic Mexicans conceived Death as the beginning of the journey to Mictlán (the Place of the Dead), during which the soul of the deceased had to overcome various obstacles before reaching Mictlantecuhtli (the Lord of the Dead) and Mictecacíhuatl (the Lady of the Dead). Upon reaching the gods of Mictlán, an offering had to be made to them in order to obtain eternal rest.

What to Expect
Claudio will explain why it is important to celebrate and take the time to honour and remember the members of your family, ancestors and loved ones who have passed away. He will also explain the mysticism and spirituality around the Day of the Dead celebration.

We’ll also learn how to set up your ofrenda, or altar, and which elements are important for it (as well their meaning).

It's very common for an ofrenda of the dead to be placed inside Mexican homes, decorated with papel picado, food, traditional sweets, and photos of loved ones. Candles and marigold flowers are also placed as a sign of welcome for our loved ones.

Feel free to bring photos of your beloved ones that have passed away, fruits and flowers for the altar and anything that your beloved ones valued / loved when they were here with us. We will place those on the altar.

The Evening’s Schedule
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

Details
When: Saturday 1 November, 7pm -9pm

Where: AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing - Level 2, 15 Johnston Street, Wellington CBD.

Investment: $55 (first 5 enrolments - $45!); Children under 16 years old - $35

Haere Mai!
Everyone is welcome including kids (see special pricing). No previous experience or knowledge is required. As this is an evening of learning and exploration, come wearing comfortable clothing! Bring an open heart and mind willing to learn and receive.

description:
GARDEN RAVE, The Garage x Jungle Juice: Wellington

Two worlds, one night.

Born in Auckland, The Garage has become one of the most recognised names in the local techno scene, creating parties that blend high-level production with an authentic underground sound.
In Wellington, Jungle Juice has built a vibrant community where everyone feels like family, connected through music, colour and the energy of every gathering.
Now, both forces come together to bring you a truly unique experience.

Location: The Garden Hotel, 63 Courtenay Place, Wellington

On the dancefloor, feel dark, driving beats and unstoppable energy. In the garden zone, enjoy a vibrant and glowing atmosphere filled with colour, lights and nature.

The Lineup (A-Z)
Andretg
DJ By Accident
Malware
Vness


The Garage and Jungle Juice unite to deliver an unforgettable techno celebration in the heart of the capital. Secure your ticket now on Humanitix and be part of this special night.


*** Important Information ***
This event is R18. Valid photo ID will be required for entry.
Respect each other and the venue.
We will not tolerate any form of discrimination.
Look out for each other and please report any antisocial behaviour.
Consent is key – always.
Lighting & Visual Effects: Please be aware that strobe lights, lasers and other flashing visuals may be in use throughout the night. These effects may not be suitable for everyone.
Photos & Video: Our crew will be capturing the energy of the night through photos and videos. By being here, you’re part of that magic and may appear in content we share to celebrate and promote future events.
Have fun and please find the crew if you have any issues.

Garden Party: Auntsfield's Firelight Soiree, Garden Party: Auntsfield's Firelight Soiree
Ready to sip, savour, and celebrate?

Nestled among rolling vines and steeped in history, Auntsfield Estate sets the scene for the official celebration of Garden Marlborough week – a vibrant cocktail evening inspired by the rich and diverse cultures of the Pacific Rim.

As flames flicker from Auntsfield’s three historic fireplaces and glowing surprises spark throughout the night, you’ll be treated to an evening of warmth, wonder, and celebration. Sip award-winning Auntsfield wines, savour a bespoke gin cocktail from Roots Gin, and indulge in bold, delicious canapés.

Colourful entertainment, live local musicians, and a touch of firelight magic will set the tone. Dress to dazzle, reconnect with old friends, and mingle with our fabulous garden owners and visiting presenters for an unforgettable finale to the region’s most-loved garden festival.

Ticket price covers entry, entertainment and all food and drinks.

Return bus transport is available from town – purchase separately on the Garden Marlborough website.

description:
Heritage Festival Open Days, Heritage Festival Open Days
Join us for an open day in the bell tower of Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, where you can uncover its unique history and see the bellringers come out to play.

Take a tour through our ringing chamber and belfry, and see our 140-year-old bells up close. You will have a chance to watch the ringers in action, and maybe even have a go at chiming our 1500kg tenor bell, the largest swinging bell in New Zealand! Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see. You may have never known that people are pulling on the ropes to make the bells ring! *One of the few towers in the world accessible by lift!

**Entry by donation**

Health & Safety
Please be aware that touching the bell ropes and access to the bells outside of the designated viewing areas is strictly prohibited. You will only be permitted to handle a bell rope under the guidance and supervision of a bellringer. Hearing protection is not required in the ringing chamber, but earmuffs will be provided whilst in the belfry viewing gallery if the bells are going to be rung.

Location
James Thomas Bell Tower, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon 6011

Come hear this award-winning vocalist (& jazz historian) with local Wellington band playing with authenticity the bawdy music that inspired such scandalous parties. description:
Jazz Festival: Alex Keatley's Sounds of the Motherland, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Double bassist, bandleader and composer Alex Keatley presents Sounds from the Motherland — a vibrant and deeply personal journey into the rich world of South African jazz. Blending the infectious grooves of Cape jazz, the joyous spirit of kwela, and the harmonic sophistication of post-bop, this project pays tribute to the music of Abdullah Ibrahim, Nduduzo Makhathini, Bheki Mseleku, and Winston Mankunku Ngozi while offering bold new compositions inspired by their legacy.

Starting this project while studying his undergraduate degree at the University of Auckland Jazz School, Alex's band consists of friends he has met during his time studying in Auckland and is excited to share with you what they have been working on for the past year. Come along and enjoy the music with us.

Featuring:

- Na'amah Cheiban
- Francesca Parussini
- Jenna Aspeling
- Will Ralph
- Iggy Palmero Epstein
- Ryan Tomov
- Finn McNeill
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Alex Trask Quartet - Imaginary Folksongs, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.
Alex Trask’s ‘Imaginary Folksongs’ blends Earth folk music with a speculative style from an imaginary place. Inspired by bluegrass, Scottish folk music, and jazz performance practice, the tunes have a simplicity in common. Free improvised sections contrast carefully arranged melodies, allowing creativity and structure to coexist. The fiddle-esque melodies and straightforward harmonies create an open and inviting sound that changes depending on the musicians on stage. Performing this music as a group invites each member to paint their private imaginings, creating a unique collective folklore. The quartet will also perform a selection of tunes that inspired the music, including songs by Brian Blade, Gordon Lightfoot, and traditional melodies.

Alex Trask – saxophone
Duncan Haynes – piano
Elijah Mulheron – bass
John Rae – drums

Ateo Buhne teams up with an amazing team to team up to go on an amazing journey to experience ateos car accident in musical form.

An experience not to miss! There will also be pieces of my wrecked proton saga for sale.

Featuring: Ateo Buhne , Nico Buhne, Lorenzo Buhne, Jack Harris. With guests: Isaac Randel and Miro “the general” Holland.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: DADS at the Undercurrent!, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

The Dancing And Drinking Society have been bringing their swing blues sounds to dance floors and craft beer bars across the capital since late 1913. When they take to the stage, guitar, horns, vocals, and kick drum blend as The Society present their favourite old rarities with exactly the sort of vigour you want for some stress relieving dance times. They’ve cultivated a decent reputation for generous and open-hearted live performance. If you feel like a decent drink and a leg shake or two, this would make for a pretty good option.

With Mat Enright, Adrian Jensen, Daniel Yeabsley, Blair Latham.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Daniel Harris Quartet, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Be prepared for a relaxing evening of traditional jazz music!

Hailing from the (not so) distant city of Christchurch, Daniel and Zachary are joined by locals Ferdinand and Oscar to deliver a wonderful blend of relaxing jazz classics. Featuring quintessential songs from the jazz age, you can rely on a wonderful evening to wash away the worries of the 21st century.

The modern jazz style often incorporates many harsher elements in order to stand out, which can be very engaging. But it often demands attention, and radiates a tense atmosphere. Vintage jazz tends to prioritize an easy listening experience, with lyrical melodies and traditional music harmony.

Settle into a chair, take a sip of wine, and let the smooth harmonies flow over you!

Featuring:

Piano: Daniel Harris
Trombone: Ferdinand Hitchings-Anstice
Bass: Zachary Chyr
Drums: Oscar Garvie
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Emy and the Car Crash, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Hailing from the mega-city of Fielding, intergalactically renowned musician, Car Crash Emy is back!


After gracing the prestigious stage of The Stomach during her Palmy-wide tour with teenage heavy metal band, Pagan Love Song, Emy is switching genre again.


Join her as she covers super-niche underground artists, such as Ella Fitzgerald and Nina Simone.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Greer Castle and Tim Honiss, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Step into a world of timeless elegance and smoky charm with this late-night jazz duet, featuring sultry vocals and masterful piano. Specialising in swing standards and heartfelt ballads, the duo brings the golden age of jazz to life with intimate interpretations and sophisticated flair.

Their setlist weaves through the Great American Songbook—think Ella Fitzgerald, Nat King Cole, Billie Holiday, and Frank Sinatra—delivering classic tunes with warmth, nuance, and a fresh personal touch.

Featuring Greer Castle and Tim Honiss.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: John Rae’s BOP-IT!, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

John Rae’s BOP-IT! Hard Bop with a Kiwi Twist.

Featuring a stellar lineup of Aotearoa’s finest jazz musicians, John
Rae’s BOP-IT! delivers a high-energy celebration of the hard bop era.
Rooted in the rich traditions of 1950s and 60s jazz, BOP-IT! brings new
life to classic repertoire while exploring the bold, boundary-pushing
spirit of post-bop.

With virtuosic solos, driving rhythms, and deep grooves, this will be
one of the most exhilarating performances of the festival. Hard bop has
always challenged both audiences and musicians alike—and BOP-IT! takes
it to the next level.

Featuring: John Rae Drums, Ben Wilcock Piano, Patrick Bleakley Bass, Oscar Laven Sax, Michael Taylor Trumpet.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Liam's And Ferd's Double Trombone Extravaganza, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

A blazing tribute to the golden age of jazz trombone quintets!

Join us for an unforgettable night as two powerhouse trombonists take the stage, backed by a red-hot rhythm section. This high-energy performance celebrates the timeless sounds of jazz legends J.J. Johnson, Kai Winding, Al Grey, and modern masters Steve Davis and Elliot Mason.

Featuring:
Liam George & Ferdinand Hitchings-Anstice – Trombones
Liam Reburn – Guitar
Jacob Hurst – Bass
Oscar Garvie – Drums
Special Guest: Daniel Yeabsley – Saxophone Giant

Expect an electrifying evening of hard-swinging grooves, smooth ballads, and bold, double-trombone brilliance – all brought to life by some of Wellington’s finest young jazz talents.

Whether you're a jazz aficionado or just love a good groove, this is a night you won't want to miss.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Lockie Bennett + 4, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Lockie Bennett + 4' is a quintet, led by Lockie Bennett, comprising some of New Zealand and Australia’s leading musicians. The quintet will be making its debut performance at The Undercurrent for the 2025 Wellington Jazz Festival. This is likely to be your only chance to catch this band in the flesh for some time. Expect to hear arrangments of songs by the great Elmo Hope, Tadd Dameron, Bud Powell and many more.

Featuring: Lockie Bennett (guitar), Mike Costeloe (trumpet), Alex Trask (saxophone), Elijah Mulheron (bass), Tim Geldens (drums)
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Luca Ciarla solOrkestra, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Luca Ciarla redraws the borders of jazz violin with a loop pedal, his voice and a wise use of electronics. He performs the entire score of his band solo, playing the violin also like a guitar, a cello or a percussion instrument.

In this imaginative musical landscape Luca sings, whistles, plays other instruments or adds new improvisations; music is continuously evolving into a dazzling solOrkestra.

The program Jazz Violin 2.0 features original compositions and unusual arrangements of jazz standards.

“…his post-Coltrane approach to ‘My Favorite Things’ was a clever way to twit a jazz classic…” The San Francisco Examiner (Usa)

Featuring LUCA CIARLA on violin, vocals, live loops and electronics
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Miro Holland's Ordinance Group, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

After a successful July undercurrent debut, Miro Holland returns -bringing with him stand up locals; Isaac Randel, Evie Patterson, Ateo and Nico Buhne- all brimming with talent. The recent cold months enraging Miro's spirit, he has returned to the light to present his new thinking. The ordinance is about stopping the nullifying wishwash, and getting everyone back to listening to each other! We will swing, dance, we will blow that's sure. There is a tendency for fiction in art that goes often ignored here, but not today! It will be bold and hopefully we will all (you included) be talking to each other, before, after, and during the gig. I think everyone in the band has lots to say and it would be a bummer if you missed out. Come!

Musicians: Miro Holland, Evie Patterson, Ateo Buhne, Nico Buhne and Isaac Randel.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Queens of the Blues, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Bye bye Gatsby! Ali Affleck is celebrating 30 years of pioneering blues and hokum (1913-1933).

Award-winning vocalist (& jazz historian) with an local kiwi musicians join forces to Celebrate the brave and bawdy blues queens who reigned in the prohibition era - many sadly forgotten over time.

'The music was bold – the women even more so! 'Masterclass in grassroots jazz/blues' ***** (Edinburgh49.org).

'Not a household name yet – she soon will be' (BBC Jazzhouse).

‘Vivacious’ (Herald).

Six-time nominee for Best Vocalist (Scottish Jazz Awards)
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: Stable Mates Sextet, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Auckland based jazz ensemble Stable Mates Sextet performs a selection of original compositions inspired by an array of influences, ranging from Wayne Shorter and Pharoah Sanders to Michael Brecker and Chris Potter. Having performed together regularly fronted by individual bandleaders in the past, the Stable Mates Sextet now joins forces as a collaborative group ready to share new works, and new interpretations of old works.

Featuring:

Charlotte Barrand - Alto Saxophone

Felix Hayes-Tourelle - Tenor Saxophone

Robin Baek - Guitar

Connor McAneny - Piano

Wil Goodinson - Bass

TBC - Guest Drummer
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: The Enigma, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Get ready for a sonic journey like no other as The Enigma takes the stage at this year’s Jazz Festival! This electrifying organ jazz trio is known for their thrilling original compositions and high-octane performances that keep audiences on the edge of their seats. Featuring Miles Crayford on the mighty Hammond organ, Mike Jensen driving the rhythm on drums, and Aleister Campbell weaving masterful guitar lines, The Enigma delivers a sound that’s both deeply rooted in jazz tradition and fearlessly experimental.

Expect the unexpected—this trio thrives on spontaneity, with compositions that twist, turn, and evolve in real time. Each performance is a living, breathing moment of musical exploration, bursting with energy, groove, and emotional depth. Whether it’s a deep-pocket groove or an explosive burst of improvisation, The Enigma creates music that’s alive with tension, playfulness, and dynamic contrast.

Don’t miss your chance to witness one of the most captivating acts on the scene. The Enigma isn't just a band—it's an experience. Catch them live and be a part of the mystery.

Featuring: Miles Crayford - Organ, Aleister Campbell - Guitar, Mike Jensen - Drums.
label: Festivals

description:
Jazz Festival: The Iggy Nama Ruci Quartet, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Led by Auckland saxophonist, Iggy Nama Ruci, the Iggy Nama Ruci quartet features a powerful interplay of musical conversation through the medium of straight-ahead jazz.

After recently touring around India and South Africa, surrounded by a plethora of Gospel jazz musicians, Iggy brings a fresh perspective and an open playfulness to the bandstand.

Michael Nash, fine-tuned Auckland pianist, draws inspiration from the likes of Brad Meldhau and Keith Jarrett, providing versatile and expressive approach to improvisation.

On double bass, Tyler Diprose acts as a grounding force, laying down a foundation, while providing rich musical intuition and connection in conversation with the band.

Max Crook brings a fiery finesse controlled by creativity and elegance to the drums. His attention to listening and reacting to the band demands constant interactive conversation.

The group will play a range of tunes from original compositions to standards by Thelonius Monk and Lennie Tristano.
label: Festivals

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers, Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.

Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.
Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!

Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
LAUNCHING Season 7 of Seeds to Feeds!, It’s time to prepare for the spring and summer ahead, join us for a meal of celebration and of planning.
We’ll share a delicious celebration meal, made with fresh, locally sourced produce, showcasing dishes that we hope will inspire menus for future harvest Celebrations.
We’ll gather together at 6 pm and spend some time getting connected and inspired.
Dinner will be served at 6.50 pm
After dinner, we will see if we can draw up some ideas, brainstorm resources and garden plans and then look at what your Harvest Festival event might be in March.
We will finish with cake (our favourite) and information on what the next steps will be.
If you are still not sure what Seeds to Feeds is all about, come join us. This is a great way to find out what will be happening in your area and how you can be involved.
RSVP’s essential so we know who we are cooking for x

description:
NZ Brewers Fest, NZ Brewers Fest
NZ Brewers Fest is moving to April!
Lining up with Fresh Hop season, we will be bringing the all the incredible beers, outstanding entertainment and delicious kai you expect, with a fresh hop twist!

Save the date and watch this space for more info, coming soon!


Drinks!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

New for this year! Step into our cocktail bar for some seriously scrumptious spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy every craving.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint.

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Otaki Waikanae Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
PUR’s 1st anniversary w/ Hang the Saints, PUR’s 1st anniversary w/ Hang the Saints
On November 1st, PUR turns one!
To mark the occasion, we’ve invited Hang The Saints — Ōtautahi’s underground techno collective.
Founded in 2024, they’ve quickly made their mark with multiple sold out club nights, hosting artists like Keepsakes, and expanding
into festival takeovers at Twisted Frequency and Lakes Festival.
Now, the crew is crossing over to Pōneke for one night only. Expect two collectives, one dancefloor, new DJs making their debut, and
sweat running until the morning. 🌑 🔊

🔗Link in bio

description:
Paekākāriki Pride Parade, Dress in your brightest colours, bring musical instruments, your dog, your friends and whanau and make some noise for the world-famous-in-Paekākāriki Pride Parade!
Assemble at 2.30pm on the sports field at Campbell Park on The Parade.

The Parade leaves Campbell Park at 3pm sharp. We'll finish up at the usual destination of St Peter's Village Hall where we'll cut the ribbon, walk across the crossing and declare it the World's Shortest Pride Parade, and celebrate eight years of Pride in the friendliest little village in the world.

Show your pride, solidarity, respect and love for and with your rainbow whanau.

description:
Self-guided Tour of Truby King Park, Self-guided Tour of Truby King Park
This Festival event runs from the 18th October to the 9th November 2025.


Discover the hidden history of Truby King Park—scan, stroll, and uncover stories with your smartphone.

Step into a garden full of stories, some inspiring, some surprising. From cherry trees and hospital wards to the people who shaped New Zealand’s early healthcare, follow the QR trail to uncover the layers of Truby King Park’s past.


Cost: Free

Event info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/self-guided-tour-of-truby-king-park-25/


Health & Safety:
This is a self-guided experience. Please explore within your limits. Wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

Parts of the park may be cordoned off for your safety. Please respect the cordons. Paths and steps may be slippery when wet.

Venue: Te Whaea: National School of Drama and Dance in Newtown, Wellington.

This year’s festival is bigger than ever! Enjoy live music from Ish, Vox Ethno, Balkany, Klezmer Rebs, Krackerjack, Cosmonauts, Wososi, and Mehana — plus traditional Polish, Ukrainian, and Bulgarian dancing.
Come and try yummy food from our Slavic and Balkan stalls (pierogi, borscht, burek, kielbasa (Polish smoked sausage), Hungarian fried bread, Blini, pirozhki), artisan crafts, kids’ workshops, and hands-on cultural fun.

description:
Slow Grind Fever [AUS] - Wellington Jazz Festival, Slow Grind Fever [AUS] - Wellington Jazz Festival
Express from Melbourne, Australia and crossing international waters for the first time this October, Meow is excited to welcome the slowest, spookiest, smokiest and swingin-est club night Wellington has ever seen: 'Slow Grind Fever'.

For this one-night-only episode of SGF Wellington, founder Richie1250 (106.7 PBS FM) will be joined by fellow Melbourne radio alumnus Dr. Popalotacorn (RRR, 98.1FM Raglan) and Wellington's own belle of the airwaves Miss Juliet (RadioActive.FM Americana)

Slow Grind Fever was born in 2012 when Richie1250 hired a Russian Cultural Centre ballroom and threw a slow dance party for his 30th birthday, and it's been running as a regular monthly club night ever since. Richie and his friends play the slowest, sleaziest, spookiest, sweetest, swinginest old records they can find, and people dance real slow in a haze of smoke and dim red light. It's a good time.

In the last few years Richie has taken Slow Grind Fever on the road, with regular dances in Sydney, Hobart, Darwin and Alice Springs. They post up a monthly Slow Grind Fever mix in the week before the party every month, and have collaborated with Stag-O Lee Records in Germany on a series of Slow Grind Fever LPs and CDs.

Enjoy the music and if you feel so inclined, get down to Slow Grind Fever - Wellington at Meow on Friday 17th October.

Listening to the MP3 mixes is nice, but when you’re in the room all
wrapped up in smoke with the music sizzling right off the old records, through the speakers and into your brain, well, there's nothing quite like it…

http://www.slowgrindfever.com/
https://www.instagram.com/slowgrindfeverclub

description:
Te Papa Foundation Gala, Wellington’s premier black-tie fundraising evening, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture.

Join us for an inspiring evening in the heart of Aotearoa New Zealand’s much-loved national museum. Feast your eyes and discover new favourites in Toi Art – the home of the National Art Collection. Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, then savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines. Bid on exclusive experiences and luxury items in our live charity auction, thanks to Webb’s. Celebrate the evening with performances from acclaimed local musicians, including Ainslie Allen and Lisa Tomlins.

All proceeds from the event support exhibitions, research, and education programmes, ensuring Te Papa continues to thrive for generations to come.

Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August to 10 September. Watch this space for more information and the link.
label: Festivals

description:
Te Papa Foundation Gala, Wellington’s premier fundraising event, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture for one spectacular night in the museum.
Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, discover new favourites in the Toi Art galleries, savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines, bid in our live charity auction, and then dance to live performances from acclaimed local musicians.
Thanks to Webb’s, the Gala features a special live auction of once-in-a-lifetime experiences, including Sake & sushi with Dick Frizzell, a stunning carving by Tim Steel (Ngāi Tahu), and luxury escapes.
Tickets cost $3,000 for a table of ten, or $300 per person.
All proceeds from the Gala supports Te Papa’s work across art, culture, history, science, and nature, ensuring that our much-loved national museum continues to thrive for generations to come.
Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August until 10 September. More information at tepapa.nz/gala.

The 2025 Upper Hutt Santa Parade is set to be another exciting event, so mark your calendars for Sunday 14 December 2025! Rain or shine Main Street on Sunday 14 December 2025 from 3.00 pm.

What’s New This Year?
This year’s Santa Parade theme is Lights, Camera, Christmas! We all have a favourite Christmas movie! Bring your favourite Christmas movie to life with a Christmas movie themed float. Whether it’s Home Alone, the Polar Express or even Die hard...

It’s not too late to get involved!
We’d love to see your creativity shine in this year's parade! Whether you're a local business, school, or community group, we encourage you to design and enter a float to bring your movie to life. One thing though we need a sign card saying the movie title on your float.

An invitation is extended to all business and community groups operating in Upper Hutt to join this community event and enter a Christmas movie themed float in the Parade.

description:
Warehouse Rave ft. Coki (UK), SYLC & Ghost Media Presents: WAREHOUSE RAVE FT. COKI
Friday 5th September
Secret Central Wellington Location (TO BE REVEALED ON EVENT DAY)
Powered by Banshee Soundsystem
7pm-1am
R18
Strictly limited capacity
Get ready Welly, because this one is about to be serious. We have secured the one and only COKI for an intimate warehouse rave at an inner city location.
This legend of bass needs no introduction, but we’ll give him one anyway. As one half of DIGITAL MYSTIKZ, Coki has made sine waves move like no other, architecting much of the sonic blueprint that modern dubstep has become known for. Alongside Mala, he helped forge the DMZ sound and is now making his way to Wellington for a rare showcase of pure low-frequency warfare. Expect heavyweight pressure, bone-rattling subs, and that unmistakable Coki wobble - this is dubstep in its rawest form.
On support we have drawn for the best of the best. Opening up proceedings we have BABETECH, champion selector and vibe master. Since murking opening slots for Loefah, Filth and Kahn & Neek as well as spreading the gospel of bass for countless evenings on RadioActive, we can’t think of a better opener for this night.
Following that, we have dubstep extraordinaire DUSTY warming things up with his signature and gruelling take on the classic dubstep sound. With releases on Infernal Sounds and Leather Kennel, Dusty has proven himself to be a force to be reckoned with, and is surely one of the most exciting young producers in the game today.
On closing duties we have the Support Your Local crew going b2b with Young Gho$t to round out the night with a bit of silliness.
We’ve managed to secure an all-new inner city warehouse location for this one, and its Further Sound on soundsystem duties this time, heating things up with their BANSHEE SOUNDSYSTEM, preparing for only its second full rollout after Cuba Dupa this year.
We’re unbelievably excited to share this space with you all for a dance and are expecting this to be one for the books.Secure your tickets now and don’t miss out on this momentous and legendary dance music event!
Tickets: https://events.humanitix.com/coki-uk-warehouse-rave
label: Festivals

With releases on Infernal Sounds and Leather Kennel, Dusty has proven himself to be a force to be reckoned with, and is surely one of the most exciting young producers in the game today.

On closing duties we have the Support Your Local crew going b2b with Young Gho$t to round out the night with a bit of silliness.

We’ve managed to secure an all-new inner city warehouse location for this one, and its Further Sound on soundsystem duties this time, heating things up with their BANSHEE SOUNDSYSTEM, preparing for only its second full rollout after Cuba Dupa this year.

We’re unbelievably excited to share this space with you all for a dance and are expecting this to be one for the books.Secure your tickets now and don’t miss out on this momentous and legendary dance music event!

Tickets: https://events.humanitix.com/coki-uk-warehouse-rave

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival 2025 | GREGORY PORTER, Hailed as one of the most influential artists of his generation, two-time GRAMMY Award-winning jazz vocalist, composer and bandleader Gregory Porter appears in Aotearoa for the first time at the Wellington Jazz Festival.
Since his breakout album Liquid Spirit on Blue Note Records, which sold over a million copies and earned him his first GRAMMY Award for Best Jazz Vocal Album in 2014, he’s captivated audiences worldwide with his soulful baritone vocals and dynamic storytelling.
Influenced by Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole, Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul and gospel with a presence that commands attention from the very first note.
A defining voice in contemporary jazz, experience his 'liquid gold' vocals, warmth, and magnetic stage presence at St James Theatre, for one night only.
label: Festivals

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival 2025 | SAMARA JOY, Five-time GRAMMY Award-winning vocalist Samara Joy makes her Aotearoa debut at the Wellington Jazz Festival.
At just 25 years old, Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation, redefining 21st century jazz with her rich tone, refined phrasing, and love and understanding of the Great American Songbook.
Since winning the GRAMMY for Best New Artist in 2023 and earning a spot on Forbes 30 Under 30 list, she has sold out major venues and headlined festivals across the globe - from Carnegie Hall to Jazz at the Lincoln Centre.
Joined by her outstanding seven-piece band at the St James Theatre, Joy will perform music from her critically acclaimed new album Portrait - praised as a “true artistic statement” (The Times) - alongside selections from her back catalogue.
Seamlessly blending the elegance of jazz’s golden age with a modern touch, be sure to secure your seats to see the unforgettable Samara Joy.
